segment.source: UEFI Firmware
segment.target: UEFI Firmware

segment.source: UEFI Firmware
segment.target: UEFI Firmware

segment.source: UEFI Firmware
segment.target: UEFI Firmware

segment.source: Here's some considerations when deploying Windows on Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI)-based devices.
segment.target: Here's some considerations when deploying Windows on Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI)-based devices.

segment.source: What is UEFI?
segment.target: What is UEFI?

segment.source: When the devices starts, the firmware interface controls the booting process of the PC, and then passes control to Windows or another operating system.
segment.target: When the devices starts, the firmware interface controls the booting process of the PC, and then passes control to Windows or another operating system.

segment.source: UEFI is a replacement for the older BIOS firmware interface and the Extensible Firmware Interface (EFI) 1.10 specifications.
segment.target: UEFI is a replacement for the older BIOS firmware interface and the Extensible Firmware Interface (EFI) 1.10 specifications.

segment.source: More than 140 leading technology companies participate in the Unified EFI Forum, including AMD, AMI, Apple, Dell, HP, IBM, Insyde, Intel, Lenovo, Microsoft, and Phoenix Technologies.
segment.target: More than 140 leading technology companies participate in the Unified EFI Forum, including AMD, AMI, Apple, Dell, HP, IBM, Insyde, Intel, Lenovo, Microsoft, and Phoenix Technologies.

segment.source: Benefits of UEFI
segment.target: Benefits of UEFI

segment.source: Firmware that meets the UEFI 2.3.1 specifications provides the following benefits:
segment.target: Firmware that meets the UEFI 2.3.1 specifications provides the following benefits:

segment.source: Faster boot and resume times.
segment.target: Faster boot and resume times.

segment.source: Ability to use security features such as Secure Boot and factory encrypted drives that help prevent untrusted code from running before the operating system is loaded.
segment.target: Ability to use security features such as Secure Boot and factory encrypted drives that help prevent untrusted code from running before the operating system is loaded.

segment.source: For more information, see Secure Boot Overview and Factory Encrypted Drives.
segment.target: For more information, see Secure Boot Overview and Factory Encrypted Drives.

segment.source: Ability to more easily support large hard drives (more than 2 terabytes) and drives with more than four partitions.
segment.target: Ability to more easily support large hard drives (more than 2 terabytes) and drives with more than four partitions.

segment.source: Compatibility with legacy BIOS.
segment.target: Compatibility with legacy BIOS.

segment.source: Some UEFI-based PCs contain a Compatibility Support Module (CSM) that emulates earlier BIOS, providing more flexibility and compatibility for end users.
segment.target: Some UEFI-based PCs contain a Compatibility Support Module (CSM) that emulates earlier BIOS, providing more flexibility and compatibility for end users.

segment.source: To use the CSM, Secure Boot must be disabled.
segment.target: To use the CSM, Secure Boot must be disabled.

segment.source: Support for multicast deployment, which allows PC manufacturers to broadcast a PC image that can be received by multiple PCs without overwhelming the network or image server.
segment.target: Support for multicast deployment, which allows PC manufacturers to broadcast a PC image that can be received by multiple PCs without overwhelming the network or image server.

segment.source: Support for UEFI firmware drivers, applications, and option ROMs.
segment.target: Support for UEFI firmware drivers, applications, and option ROMs.

segment.source: Additional advantages are described in the Intel EFI and UEFI Overview and Specifications.
segment.target: Additional advantages are described in the Intel EFI and UEFI Overview and Specifications.

segment.source: Windows support of UEFI
segment.target: Windows support of UEFI

segment.source: The following Windows editions include support for UEFI:
segment.target: The following Windows editions include support for UEFI:

segment.source: Windows 10 for desktop editions (Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education), Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview, Windows 8.1, and Windows 8 support native UEFI 2.0 or later on 32-bit (x86), 64-bit (x64), and ARM-based PCs.
segment.target: Windows 10 for desktop editions (Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education), Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview, Windows 8.1, and Windows 8 support native UEFI 2.0 or later on 32-bit (x86), 64-bit (x64), and ARM-based PCs.

segment.source: They also support BIOS-based PCs, and UEFI-based PCs running in legacy BIOS-compatibility mode.
segment.target: They also support BIOS-based PCs, and UEFI-based PCs running in legacy BIOS-compatibility mode.

segment.source: Some features such as Secure Boot require UEFI 2.3.1 Errata C or higher.
segment.target: Some features such as Secure Boot require UEFI 2.3.1 Errata C or higher.

segment.source: Windows Server 2012 R2 and Windows Server® 2012 support native UEFI 2.0 or later on 64-bit systems.
segment.target: Windows Server 2012 R2 and Windows Server® 2012 support native UEFI 2.0 or later on 64-bit systems.

segment.source: Some features such as Secure Boot require UEFI 2.3.1.
segment.target: Some features such as Secure Boot require UEFI 2.3.1.

segment.source: Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2:
segment.target: Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2:

segment.source: Support UEFI 2.0 or later on 64-bit systems.
segment.target: Support UEFI 2.0 or later on 64-bit systems.

segment.source: They also support BIOS-based PCs, and UEFI-based PCs running in legacy BIOS-compatibility mode.
segment.target: They also support BIOS-based PCs, and UEFI-based PCs running in legacy BIOS-compatibility mode.

segment.source: Support on Class 2 systems running in legacy BIOS-compatibility mode by using a CSM, so they can use the legacy BIOS INT10 features.
segment.target: Support on Class 2 systems running in legacy BIOS-compatibility mode by using a CSM, so they can use the legacy BIOS INT10 features.

segment.source: Are not supported on Class 3 systems, because these operating systems assume the presence of legacy BIOS INT10 support in the firmware, which is not available in a Class-3 UEFI implementation.
segment.target: Are not supported on Class 3 systems, because these operating systems assume the presence of legacy BIOS INT10 support in the firmware, which is not available in a Class-3 UEFI implementation.

segment.source: Windows Server 2008 R2 also supports EFI 1.10 on Itanium-based systems.
segment.target: Windows Server 2008 R2 also supports EFI 1.10 on Itanium-based systems.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: While in UEFI mode, the Windows version must match the PC architecture.
segment.target: While in UEFI mode, the Windows version must match the PC architecture.

segment.source: A 64-bit UEFI PC can only boot 64-bit versions of Windows.
segment.target: A 64-bit UEFI PC can only boot 64-bit versions of Windows.

segment.source: A 32-bit PC can only boot 32-bit versions of Windows.
segment.target: A 32-bit PC can only boot 32-bit versions of Windows.

segment.source: In some cases, while in legacy BIOS mode, you may be able to run 32-bit Windows on a 64-bit PC, assuming the manufacturer supports 32-bit legacy BIOS mode on the PC.
segment.target: In some cases, while in legacy BIOS mode, you may be able to run 32-bit Windows on a 64-bit PC, assuming the manufacturer supports 32-bit legacy BIOS mode on the PC.

segment.source: Windows supports a subset of the functionality that is defined in the UEFI specification.
segment.target: Windows supports a subset of the functionality that is defined in the UEFI specification.

segment.source: Windows implementations do not explicitly check against higher revisions of the firmware
segment.target: Windows implementations do not explicitly check against higher revisions of the firmware

segment.source: For additional UEFI requirements, see UEFI Installation Media Format and default boot behavior and UEFI Requirements: Boot time, Runtime, Hibernation State (S4).
segment.target: For additional UEFI requirements, see UEFI Installation Media Format and default boot behavior and UEFI Requirements: Boot time, Runtime, Hibernation State (S4).

segment.source: Before You Begin
segment.target: Before You Begin

segment.source: Before you install Windows on a UEFI-based PC, note the following:
segment.target: Before you install Windows on a UEFI-based PC, note the following:

segment.source: For some platforms or hardware configurations, you may need to perform additional steps to make sure that Windows is installed in UEFI mode or in legacy BIOS-compatibility mode.
segment.target: For some platforms or hardware configurations, you may need to perform additional steps to make sure that Windows is installed in UEFI mode or in legacy BIOS-compatibility mode.

segment.source: For more information, see Boot to UEFI Mode or Legacy BIOS mode.
segment.target: For more information, see Boot to UEFI Mode or Legacy BIOS mode.

segment.source: UEFI hard disks require the GUID partition table (GPT) partition structure, instead of the master boot record (MBR) partition structure that is used in BIOS.
segment.target: UEFI hard disks require the GUID partition table (GPT) partition structure, instead of the master boot record (MBR) partition structure that is used in BIOS.

segment.source: When you install Windows by using the Windows product DVD, Windows Setup detects whether the PC was booted in UEFI mode or BIOS-compatibility mode, and it configures Windows based on this selection.
segment.target: When you install Windows by using the Windows product DVD, Windows Setup detects whether the PC was booted in UEFI mode or BIOS-compatibility mode, and it configures Windows based on this selection.

segment.source: Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) can be configured to support both UEFI mode and BIOS-compatibility mode.
segment.target: Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) can be configured to support both UEFI mode and BIOS-compatibility mode.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: While the PC is in UEFI mode, the Windows PE version must match the PC architecture.
segment.target: While the PC is in UEFI mode, the Windows PE version must match the PC architecture.

segment.source: A PC in 64-bit UEFI firmware mode can only boot 64-bit versions of Windows PE.
segment.target: A PC in 64-bit UEFI firmware mode can only boot 64-bit versions of Windows PE.

segment.source: A PC in 32-bit UEFI firmware mode can only boot 32-bit versions of Windows PE.
segment.target: A PC in 32-bit UEFI firmware mode can only boot 32-bit versions of Windows PE.

segment.source: On PCs that support both UEFI mode and legacy BIOS mode, you may be able to run 32-bit Windows PE on a 64-bit PC by changing BIOS menu settings from “UEFI mode” to “BIOS mode”, assuming the manufacturer supports legacy BIOS mode.
segment.target: On PCs that support both UEFI mode and legacy BIOS mode, you may be able to run 32-bit Windows PE on a 64-bit PC by changing BIOS menu settings from “UEFI mode” to “BIOS mode”, assuming the manufacturer supports legacy BIOS mode.

segment.source: For instructions, see WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive or WinPE: Install on a Hard Drive (Flat Boot or Non-RAM).
segment.target: For instructions, see WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive or WinPE: Install on a Hard Drive (Flat Boot or Non-RAM).

segment.source: Note to firmware manufacturers: Do not use tools or applications to alter Windows-specific boot files, including files in the C:boot and C:EFI folders.
segment.target: Note to firmware manufacturers: Do not use tools or applications to alter Windows-specific boot files, including files in the C:boot and C:EFI folders.

segment.source: Altering these files could interfere with the PC’s ability to boot up, to resume from hibernation, or to run system recovery tools.
segment.target: Altering these files could interfere with the PC’s ability to boot up, to resume from hibernation, or to run system recovery tools.

segment.source: Instead, use tools such as BCDboot to set the boot order.
segment.target: Instead, use tools such as BCDboot to set the boot order.

segment.source: For more info, see BCDboot Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more info, see BCDboot Command-Line Options.

segment.target: See Also
